replies.author: @aela3786
replies.text:
Fellow trans person (trans woman) - I'm cynical to the idea that we actually have a path into acceptance. 

I think we can get some legislation piggy-backing onto something else around broad protections or medical autonomy, and some specific locations are friendly, but I don't think most people will ever normalize being trans. 

It's just a completely foreign concept in a world where cis women are still oppressed. We're not jumping the line, and that one hasn't been sorted out even. 

I'm gonna keep living my life but I honestly prioritize other people's struggles over my own because it's not one I see as worth the time and energy it takes.

replies.author: @cedaremberr
replies.text: ‚Äã@aela3786 I agree that trans liberation isn't achievable in our lifetimes, but that doesn't mean we can't improve things. replies.author: @roxyamused
replies.text:
I share in your cynicism that trans people won't have full acceptance @aela3786, but I'd add  Historically, you're incorrect that being trans will never be "normalized" accepted part of society as it has in the past- why could it not again? Many times in history though, a form of trans identity still wasn't treated as average either, sometimes an exalted part of the community.¬†

That being said, we don't find ourselves in ancient Sumer or something, but in the US in 2024 after an election where the right spent $222million on anti-trans messaging for trump. I don't even think that counts the many down ballot  races that even democrats got in on the fun. So I share in your despair. I think that it that piggy-backing on larger bills is a step toward normalization. All liberation is ultimately interdependent and interconnected anyway. Your fight for other struggles endears other oppressed peoples to our liberation. So you are fighting for our liberation whether you like it or not, it is interconnected. Fighting for future generations is not a hopeless endeavor, and us just being as we are is enough. Living our trans lives as if they matter, on some level unfortunately, is a form of resistance towards liberation.

replies.author: @PhotonBeast
replies.text:
I wish I had some resources to help with those discussions, but I don't know, sadly. I understand, sympathize, and empathize with you, though. It feels frustrating because like... you haven't changed at the heart of you. You are you. Always have been. Might have taken some time to find it, as we all do, but it's always been you. A fire can say it was born from a stroke of lightning or a splash of lava. But what can the wind say on why it is when it has always been?

Best I can offer, I suppose, is to accept what can be changed... and try to move on from what can not. Be safe, live free and with dignity, help those who need it, and form bonds with those who wish it and desire it. And maybe those friends and family who will not yet come with you will decide that life without you is worse than life with you. Maybe then they will then take the effort to step forward and take your hand again and enjoy the colour you bring to the world.

replies.author: @erinmac4750
replies.text:
I have to say that I didn't see people reversing their acceptance of their trans family or friends as a possibility. If someone's accepted in my circle, they'd literally have to deliberately hurt me or be toxic to me or others. If I let someone in, it's because I accept them for their authentic selves and trust that they do the same for me. Needless to say I don't have a lot of friends because respect, empathy, and integrity aren't common these days, especially in this country. 
For myself, because of this latest twist in our politics, I'm thinking that I need to find "safe" groups, as well as ones who will continue to advocate for marginalized people. 
I hope you're able to find new more genuine people and have a group of true friends that are actually there for you. üíúüçÄ

author: @LoreTheDarkElf
text:
I've known this my whole life. 80% of people don't care and will choose to be the bully over risking victimhood. 

We saw it in school. Everyone knew who the bullied kids were. The kids knew, the teachers knew, the lunch staff knew. 

And Those with authority Did Nothing while the majority of the student body lived in fear of Being One Of Those Kids. 

We've always known our peers would rather be cruel if it means they get the tension release of it Not Being Them. Seeing someone else brutalized reassures them that They Are Safe. Someone else is getting it.

I have been the bullied kid my entire life. I have been ignored when trampled, I have watched adults look away when I cried out for help and had to SCREAM to get them to act. I have watched my peers ignore me crying in the middle of a room to go about their lunch period in peace. 

If you never talked to the bullied kid, if you decided that bottom rung of Special Ed and Oddballs was below you... you've been part of this since before you knew your multiplication tables. 

Cruelty is begging not to be the one stepped on by hurriedly stomping on someone else and hoping others follow suit. And American children knew their part by preschool.

I‚Äôm so so sorry all that happened. As someone who stood up for bullied kids when I was young, & always sought to include others who appeared alone with me & my friends, it boggles the mind when people just stand by. The only time I‚Äôve didn‚Äôt do that is when I was older & thought stepping in would embarrass or hurt someone further, like if it was male on male bullying (me being a girl I was also told by at least 2 male people being victimized to please stop - we were teens by then). I wish people had stood up for you, stuck their neck out. I wish things were different now. I could never stand a bully. Just bc I am louder & generally confident, I was often spared by bullies or rather, I would bully them back, which didn‚Äôt really fix the problem as it still damaged my emotional health. 

All I know is there is safety in numbers & there is no greater sin than cowardice or apathy when you have the power to change something. As an adult I‚Äôve become soo much more complacent. I lost the confidence to act or speak that I had a kid, but I haven‚Äôt lost the ideals. I will no longer let my fellow human being with power slide if they have any form of power to do something. This goes for in public & in private.

replies.author: @erinmac4750
replies.text:
Your comment hits hard. 
As someone who was bullied through much of my schooling, I can  totally relate. In my case, I was fortunate/blessed to have some awesome teachers who did actually look out for me. Mostly they would just make sure they talked to me, but I had a couple who would give me stuff to do or let me go run laps around the playground if I was too hyper. Being in class became a safe space for me. 
Now, as an educator, hearing about situations like yours, where no one intervened, or worse yet actively ignored is angering and heartbreaking. In my classes, I have zero tolerance for bullying or bigotry of any kind. Many of my students come from rough home situations, so I want them to feel safe in my class. 
When I have seen issues, they're handled, even if it means me physically getting in between. I know that not all teachers or administrators are like that, but I've been impressed on how many who are in my school district. 
No one deserves to be treated less than, especially kids in a school setting. School is supposed to be a safe space, so that kids can learn. 

That said, I hope you have a good support network now. Having "people" or community is important. Also, hopefully you have access to good MH care when you need it. That's another problem in this country. The fact that adequate MH care isn't available to many. 
I wish you the best through these insane times. üçÄ

replies.author: @human-beingggggg
replies.text:
I remember when I changed schools to escape my bullies, and then, on the very first day, this one kid targeted me. He was short and overweight, with a migrant background and arabic name. It just so happened that my mother had known his dad who had been stabbed to death when he was small. And she recognized the fact he bullied me to avoid being targeted himself, and due to trauma. He was the class clown so that the cool kids would "accept" him. It was even suggested to me that maybe he has a crush on me. But, you know, I don't care. 

I don't care about these people's sob stories. I don't care about their motivations. This kid could have joined our group of misfits, make real friends who don't just tolerate him. I did hear years later that he grew up to regret it and speak out against bullying, and I'm glad. Everyone should do that. But he had chosen to be a coward and hurt others. I've tried and tried to understand, but what of the trauma and stories of the rest of us? Who will understand us, if not even all of us?

replies.author: @kobaltkween
replies.text:
That's simple.  Race and capitalism were invented together to leverage and control European commoners for the enrichment of the peerage, who were basically the only people who had capital to invest.  Colonies were capitalist investments of the various monarchies.  And as they grew, race was refined as a legal and cultural tool to exploit various people for greater and greater profits.

For example, take the major rebellion in colonial NYC.  Indentured servants, indigenous people, and enslaved Africans united and almost succeeded in overthrowing the wealthy, powerful rulers.    When the powerful won, they deliberately gave each racial group separate and unequal punishment.  They were fairly light on the whites, harsh on the indigenous people including banishment, and publicly tortured the enslaved Africans.  Most notably killing the leader by "slow burning" him alive for 7 to 9 hours.  They then outlawed fraternization among the three groups.

The "American dream" involves owning land, because it's the European commoner's dream of becoming a member of the peerage.  That inherently implies serfs to enrich the new peerage.  Those serfs, globally, have been African and American indigenous peoples, and Asian and Middle Eastern peoples to a lesser and generally more recent extent.

When capitalism fails, the powerful use race and ethnic bigotry, a romantization of the height of imperialism and racial/ethnic exploitation, and the promise of being rewarded for joining and obeying the cult of whiteness that was and is foundational to capitalism to prevent major class gains.  

The whole reason European nations have more liberal governments is that their resident racial minorities have been much fewer.  No one is going to forego universal healthcare just to spite a tiny bit of immigrants and Roma or Irish Travelers.  But it's not an accident that British conservatives Britain have been able to chip away at the NHS as their colonial power has waned, and non-white citizens of those former colonies have moved to where their countries' wealth has gone.

replies.author: @teegee7801
replies.text:
@josephmarch7142  Why not go back the this?: "Life for American and immigrant families during the Industrial Revolution in the late 19th and early 20th centuries was marked by significant challenges and hardships. The rapid industrialization of the United States brought about profound changes in family life, work conditions, and social structures. Here is an overview of what family life was like during this period:

1. Working Conditions
Factory Work: Many American and immigrant families worked in factories, where conditions were often harsh and dangerous. Workers, including children, labored for long hours in poorly ventilated, noisy, and unsafe environments.

Long Hours: It was common for workers to work 10 to 16 hours a day, six days a week. The lack of regulated work hours meant that families had little time to spend together.

Low Wages: Wages were extremely low, especially for unskilled laborers. Many families struggled to make ends meet, and even with multiple family members working, they often lived in poverty.

Child Labor: Child labor was prevalent, with children as young as five or six working in factories, mines, and mills. This deprived them of education and a normal childhood.

2. Living Conditions
Tenements and Slums: Many families lived in overcrowded and unsanitary tenements or slums near industrial areas. These dwellings were often poorly constructed, with inadequate ventilation, heating, and sanitation.

Health Hazards: The lack of proper sanitation and healthcare led to the spread of diseases such as tuberculosis, cholera, and typhoid. Infant mortality rates were high, and life expectancy was low.

Lack of Privacy: Living spaces were cramped, with multiple families sometimes sharing a single apartment. This lack of privacy and personal space added to the stress and strain on family life.

3. Family Structure
Nuclear Family: While the ideal of the nuclear family (parents and their children) existed, the reality was often different. Extended family members, such as grandparents, aunts, and uncles, might live together or nearby to provide support.

Role of Women: Women played a crucial role in maintaining family life. In addition to working in factories or taking in piecework, they were responsible for managing the household, cooking, cleaning, and caring for children.

Children: Children often contributed to the family income by working in factories or performing domestic tasks. Education was often secondary to the need for income, and many children had limited access to schooling.

4. Immigrant Families
Ethnic Enclaves: Immigrant families often settled in ethnic enclaves, where they could find support from their community. These enclaves provided a sense of belonging and cultural continuity.

Language Barriers: Many immigrants faced language barriers and discrimination, which made it difficult to integrate into American society and find better-paying jobs.

Cultural Adaptation: Immigrant families had to navigate the challenges of adapting to a new culture while preserving their own traditions and values. This often created tension between generations.

5. Wages and Economic Struggles
Low Wages: Wages for factory workers were barely enough to cover basic living expenses. Many families lived paycheck to paycheck, with little to no savings for emergencies.

Economic Instability: The industrial economy was volatile, with frequent layoffs, strikes, and economic downturns. This instability made it difficult for families to maintain a consistent income.

Company Towns: In some cases, workers lived in company towns, where the company owned the housing, stores, and other services. This often led to exploitation, with workers paying inflated prices for goods and services.

6. Social and Political Movements
Labor Unions: The harsh conditions of industrial work led to the rise of labor unions, which fought for better wages, shorter hours, and safer working conditions. Strikes and labor activism were common, though often met with violent repression.
Progressive Reforms: The Progressive Era (late 19th to early 20th century) saw the emergence of social and political reforms aimed at addressing the issues faced by industrial workers. These reforms included child labor laws, workplace safety regulations, and the establishment of a minimum wage.
Conclusion
Life for American and immigrant families during the Industrial Revolution was characterized by harsh working conditions, low wages, and challenging living conditions. While the nuclear family ideal existed, the reality was often more complex, with extended family members and community support playing crucial roles. The economic struggles and social challenges of this period led to significant social and political movements that sought to improve the lives of industrial workers and their families."

replies.author: @Singlesix6
replies.text:
"if only we had Medi-Care for all"

I'm on Medicare. I enrolled in 2015. Medicare Part A is free and Part B costs a minimum of $185 PER MONTH. Medicare does not cover everything, so a supplemental policy is needed. That costs me $320 per month, but does include a little dental and vision coverage. Oh, and prescription coverage is extra. My prescription coverage is included in the $320/month I pay for the supplemental Anthem plan. And there are copays and other charges that neither one covers. Health insurance is not cheap, even if you have worked full-time for 38 years like I did and paid into the Soc Sec system with every paycheck.
(The reason I said Part B cost a minimum of $185 per month is because people with high retirement income can pay more than $500 a month for Part B. There's a 5-step scale that's available on line. Yeah, you need to be well off income wise to get hammered by the IRMAA surcharge for something you think you've already paid for during decades of work. It is what it is.)

Medicare is not a solution for people who cannot afford the premiums and the copays There is Medicaid, similar but different, but there again it doesn't cover everything.

There is always the option of the Advantage plans we all see advertised on tv. The ones where coverage is free or almost free and they give you money every month for other things. Medicare pays them to cover you and pay you and guess who makes the decisions about what medical services get approved. They do. Same old, same old.

author: @Moonflight021
text:
My grandma is a maga conservative and we'll sometimes speak with each other about politics--very respectfully, of course. There are a lot of (false!) right-wing worldview assumptions that I have to navigate in order to have an actual discussion with her.

We talked about Palestine a while ago: Assuming every single right-wing talking point is actually correct regarding the genocide (from her perspective), how do I get her to begin to empathize with these people, invite her to maybe be open to listening to their story? What's the first step?

I talked about the apartheid (although I avoided calling it that), about the conditions that Israel imposes upon them. I talked about how if I had been born in Palestine, I probably would have joined Hamas; that I probably would have felt like I had no other way to change my situation.

I managed to get her to think, just a little bit, about a different perspective. If I had come out of the gate with "Israel is a genocidal apartheid state illegally occupying and colonizing Palestine and the Gaza strip," (an absolutely irrevocably true statement!) she would have shut down and never listened.

replies.text: I would suggest maybe it's fair to blame the racism and misogyny for not converting more "independant" right wingers, but it seems extremely myopic to blame that for the lack of turn out to support the non-Fash candidate. I mean, who are those who stayed home instead of voting for Biden part 2? I think critiques like this assume that the non-voters are somehow by default exactly evenly distributed across all demographics, but that would be a mistake. For starters, we know that the youngest cohort of potential voters was one of the biggest blocs of people who didn't vote. That should tell you something.

replies.author: @medsocsci
replies.text: @weatheranddarkness Young voters always have the lowest turnout rate among age groups. Gen Z men are also doing the opposite of Millennials; they're moving to the right at a young age. Isn't it ironic that Biden is a white man, and the two people who lost to Trump are women? Biden has always been known as a centrist Democrat, yet people still came out to vote for him. On the right, Harris is well-known for having a far more liberal Senate record than Biden did. It's frustrating that the right was aware of Harris' progressive record while people on the left believed Tulsi Gabbard's lies.

replies.author: @FallingIn2TheVoid
replies.text:
@weatheranddarkness I think that you're forgetting the once in a generation global pandemic that Trump badly mishandled. That is a huge motivator to a lot of people to get out and vote Trump out of office who are otherwise apolitical and apathetic. The pandemic influenced people to vote who otherwise wouldn't, and no amount of messaging or outreach will ever counteract that. Also, many people stayed home because they don't like Trump as a person but also felt Kamala was "too radical"; I personally know several of them. They would have voted Republican if DeSantis or Haley was the R nominee. I'm not saying voter outreach isn't important, it obviously is, but you cannot ignore the role of the COVID-19 pandemic in mobilizing people against Trump in 2020 when asking why so many people voted for Biden and not Harris.

Edit: It was also extremely easy to vote in 2020 because of the pandemic making vote by mail more accessible than it normally is. That is HUGE in getting lazy, disabled or extremely busy people to vote.

author: @wolframstahl1263
text:
Discourse has moved away from being constructive and away from reality based arguments. We are so used to people arguing that something IS factual because they WANT it to be, that we're inclined to infer in the opposite direction as well: if you argue something IS factual, that implies that you WANT it to be true.

That's absurd, but we see this kind of absurdity enough that it becomes a 'habit of thought' rather that the result of an actual evaluation of evidence.
We need to convince people again that our beliefs should (and can, even) be shaped by reality rather than our perception of what is real being shaped by what we do, want to, or profess to believe.

author: @markkairial
text: It's not just the US. It's the whole world. We need system change globally. No more 'they' should (complaining) but rather 'we' should (solving issues). The caste system still exists and needs to be broken down. 'Black' is a term that strengthens the caste system. Isabel Wilkerson wrote that an African told her, "there are no 'black' people in Africa". 'Race' is another term that needs to be dropped. It is a made up concept, There is only one race, the human race. I try my best not to use those terms. If you call someone racist you are accepting it as a reality. Call people prejudiced or bigoted, colorist or nosist or curly hair haters. As I say these things I also know that changing people's attitudes won't work. Changing systems will. If there is a good enough suggestion for what to do and how to do it, it will be done. I am working on it. Policies without Politicians. Saw Tooth not Pyramid. Everyone who wants a say has a say. Change one aspect of social organization at a time. Health and Education probably come first. Food, finance and arms come a close second. Global constitutions with local considerations are needed. Traffic lights stop us but they also allow access to all. People may come on board if the benefits are obvious and there is no alliance with current political persuasions. This is a huge shift in our social organizational approach. I hope to publish soon, possibly on substack. It will be the beginning of a plan and a strategy for transition. All are invited to have input and discussion. I will not live to see it completed but I hope to see it started. Obviously there is not enough space here to elaborate but perhaps I can spark a few like minded people. Thanks to anyone who made it this far into my rave. And finally thanks, Olurinatti.

I see a lot of leftists who seem more concerned about the Democrats winning an election than the people who are suffering in this country. @ericbrooks939
Hope you didn‚Äôt vote for Trump then, cause your wallet won‚Äôt be happy with your decision. 

The point of tariffs is to make something from outside the market to be in the higher price. Trump is pro tariffs, even his republican project 2025 mentions that. 

Say you are selling a product that you produced. In your area; it is priced at ‚Äúx‚Äù. You then want to sell to another state/country, but they have tariffs ‚Äút‚Äù. You simply add ‚Äút‚Äù to ‚Äúx‚Äù in that state/country when selling over there. This helps locals sell their same products as yours for a lower price. But if other companies are buying and using your products to make a unique product, then they have to add that ‚Äút‚Äù to their prices. 

It doesn‚Äôt matter what the candidate promises as much as their teams project documents promises. The project plans is made by that said team and will be carried out by that said teem, especially if they out number the other teams. That‚Äôs why you were supposed to read before voting.

author: @spontaneousmixx
text:
Answer, bold and CLEAR messaging.  Universality of policies and programs, speaking to the concerns and anxieties that affect ALL Americans (i.e. economic populism), and dismiss attacks on character and refocus criticisms on the policies that the majority of the people want.  Don't capitulate to right wing framing of made up problems that don't actually exist. 

 Democrats lost because if terrible messaging and poor leadership.  They lost because a strategist idea of a moderate is someone who rides the middle rather than somebody who hates both parties.  They lost because they means test, and focus group, and make decisions based on individualized demographics.   Too much focus on that which is a moral issue (abortion) with not enough on economic issues.  Middle voters go back and forth when they didn't get the change they were expecting from the last guy. 

Democrats are financially incentived by the billionaire, Robber Baron class to fail though.  

The strategy, is to replace the DNC leadership with someone who will get corporate money out of politics.  Fight for universal programs like Medicare for all, Pre-K, childcare, housing as a right, education as a right, 4 day work week. Actual economic policies that ALL Americans will FEEL.  And then DEMONIZE the wealthy oligarchs who fight against it.  Class warfare. Eat the rich.  

The sentiment of most people who stay home and don't bother to vote, that would be Democratic voters otherwise, is that it don't matter because both parties are corrupt.  Both parties captured by the billionaire class.

So long as made up social issues are made to be the forefront of political discourse, the billionaire class will always use the corporate media apparatus to manufacture consent, and trick people into either staying home, or voting against their own interests. 

Messaging, leadership, economic populism.  That is the plan

text: I agree with a lot of this but this analysis feels a little incomplete insofar as you don't really talk about people who don't vote? You mention the preconceived biases of the average American but a plurality of Americans don't meaningfully support anything. I think that "convincing conservatives or moderates" is one way to win but I feel like if we need a "plan" over the next four/eight/ten+ years, it's way more prudent to attract the millions of folks who don't need to be convinced to vote for a new party but to vote at all, especially when most of those people are also PoC and young to begin with.

replies.author: @wonder-witch
replies.text:
Yup. I think the 2020 election really proved that accessibility is the answer here. People keep citing how there was lower turnout this election (and there was, but now that it‚Äôs been a while, it‚Äôs clear it wasn‚Äôt as wide of a gap as we thought) without mentioning the amount of mail-in ballots in 2020 due to the pandemic. People that are too preoccupied/overwhelmed need it to be as easy as possible. The lack of accessibility has to do with all the red tape and gerrymandering, but speaking on a personal note, the school I teach at has been really successful at creating incentives to get our HS seniors that are of age to vote. Counselor gets everyone registered during a study hall period, and there‚Äôs a dedicated day where we take the kids to vote (a field trip basically) and get them lunch.  

It‚Äôs going to come down to community initiatives and targeting legislation in your area that makes it harder for people to vote. Republicans know this‚Ä¶ you should see how they move in nursing homes and senior communities. That‚Äôs why their turnouts are so high üòÇ

author: @abolishpolice5232
text:
Ehh‚Ä¶I agree in part, but there‚Äôs a few complications. Americans truly do not have coherent beliefs. Voters are operating on pure vibes. We‚Äôve seen before how support for progressive policies can be achieved when it is disconnected from ‚Äúprogressivism‚Äù in the minds of the public. I mean, there‚Äôs a decent amount of right wing support for legalizing weed that will evaporate in a heartbeat if Dems choose to campaign on it.
There was a slew of studies after 2016 attempting to explain the results of that election, and by far the best predictor of support for Trump is an inclination toward authoritarianism. *How did researchers measure authoritarianism? By measuring people‚Äôs views of parenting.* People who support the subjugation of children will support the subjugation of any other group. And it kind of doesn‚Äôt matter what else they might believe, to an extent, because they believe that people should not have control over their lives. They kind of want to just surrender themselves over to whoever promises to be in control.
TBH, I don‚Äôt see a solution to this that does not include child liberation. There need to be a real serious challenge to the concept of ‚Äúparent‚Äôs rights‚Äù and it needs to have teeth.

author: @theschafer5367
text:
I'm a white person who talks to coworkers and acquaintances quite often about leftist topics, and I don't know to what extent I'm viewed as an insufferable interlocutor by most in earshot, but I feel like I see a lot of success in these conversations, and a lot of people who used to say they were libertarians (or "classical liberals") are pretty radically left in my social circle.

I don't know if I can say I've found the secret ingredient or whatever, but I've always hated buzzwords, and unfortunately, "the left," "progressive," obviously "woke," "inclusive" and many such words are in this category. I'm actually alarmed at how fast the buzzword umbrella is increasing.

Anyway, it's kinda sad when you put it in the way that "you have to trick people," but the truth is that we're taught a lot of things about how we're supposed to treat or regard people as kids that becomes... just sort of background noise as we grow up? A lot of people seem to lose sight of how things should be, but it's also easy to remind them that people shouldn't be bankrupted over a broken arm, and minority groups should be protected because everybody should be protected, right?

These things really are apolitical when you scrape off the buzzwords. When people see both left and right as a valid choice, they don't yet know how antithetical the US right is to common sense. They need to be reminded what the common sense is and that wanting the best for other people isn't just a childish fantasy that they need to let go in order to grow up. Unfortunately, all the major news media organizations and personalities seem to be screaming this message at us 24/7. Even the "liberal" ones.
